title: Multiple Sclerosis: Vestibular and Central Auditory Findings
chief_complaint: I have these terrible headaches on the right side and nausea, especially when I turn my head. I feel constantly unsteady, like a 'spaciness' or being off-balance, and my neck hurts on the right side.

problem_summary.onset: 2 months prior to referral at the medical center.
problem_summary.course: Initial symptoms of vertigo and nausea were treated as BPPV/viral labyrinthitis with Antivert. Symptoms persisted. Later developed right facial numbness and reduced tongue sensation.
problem_summary.laterality: Right-sided symptoms (headache, neck pain, facial numbness) with bilateral but asymmetric central findings.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Nausea, headaches, neck pain, unsteadiness, right facial numbness, reduced sensation on right side of tongue.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Persistent feeling of unsteadiness aggravated by head-turning; headaches occurring approximately twice weekly.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking explanation for persistent symptoms after initial treatment failed.

history.present_illness: Patient presented 2 months post-onset of right-sided headaches and nausea. Previous community evaluation (CT and audio) was normal; treated for BPPV without success. Current complaints include 'spaciness' and off-balance feeling aggravated by head turning.
history.otologic_history: Prior diagnosis of benign paroxysmal vertigo secondary to viral labyrinthitis.
history.medical_psych_history: Familial history of Multiple Sclerosis (mother diagnosed at age 21), diabetes, and Parkinson's disease. Patient later developed right facial numbness.
history.prior_management: Treated with Antivert (ineffective). Later treated with Tavist and Ciprofloxin (symptoms improved in 4 days, but headaches persisted).
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of unsteadiness and neurological symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Peripheral findings fell within normal limits for both ears.

tests.name: Electronystagmography (ENG)
tests.key_findings: Left-beating nystagmus noted with eyes closed.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Left ear: Normal at slow and high repetition rates. Right ear: Normal latencies at slow rate (15.7/sec) but poor Wave V morphology. At high repetition rate (65.7/sec), Wave V disappeared completely.

tests.name: Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear stimulation resulted in a meager Pa response at all electrode sites. Left ear stimulation yielded a strong Na-Pa complex.

tests.name: Speech audiometry (Dichotic)
tests.key_findings: Dichotic digit results were normal for both ears. Dichotic CV scores were borderline abnormal for the left ear.

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Discrete and asymmetrical high intensity lesions in periventricular white matter. Increased signals bilaterally (Left > Right). Plaques evident in the brainstem.

tests.name: Visual Evoked Responses
tests.key_findings: Definite delays of P2 latency for the right side, consistent with intrinsic lesion of anterior visual pathway.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal peripheral hearing sensitivity but significant central auditory nervous system findings consistent with Multiple Sclerosis. While standard ABR latencies were normal, high-repetition rate ABR revealed a complete disappearance of Wave V in the right ear, indicating neural transmission fatigue/inefficiency. MLR was abnormal with right ear stimulation. These auditory findings correlate with the right-sided facial numbness and MRI findings of brainstem plaques and periventricular lesions.
counseling_points: Explain that hearing sensitivity (ability to hear beeps) is normal, but the pathways carrying sound to the brain are showing signs of stress, specifically on the right side.
Discuss the correlation between the 'spaciness'/balance issues and the central nervous system findings.
Review the impact of Multiple Sclerosis on the auditory system, noting that symptoms can fluctuate.
Highlight the importance of the high-rate ABR test in detecting the problem, as standard tests appeared normal.
Recommend continued monitoring of auditory and vestibular function.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is frustrated by previous 'normal' test results despite feeling persistently unwell.
Emphasize the sensation of 'spaciness' rather than spinning vertigo.
Mention the family history of MS with anxiety/concern, as your mother was diagnosed young.
When describing the headaches, localize them to the right side and mention the neck pain.
